item.title: Development of a lifeplace questionnaire
item.description: Background There are two parts required to conduct a study on health and place across the lifecourse: Longitudinal information on the environment Information on residential location This blogpost focusses on the latter. This information might be collected prospectively via routine administrative records (e.g. GP location), which could be linked to health records. However, for a number of research questions we might want to understand non-routinely collected information (e.g. tobacco smoking history), which is available in a number of cohort studies.
